citation.article-title: Clostridium fervidus sp. nov., a new chemoorganotrophic acetogenic thermophile.

p.s: Description of Clostridium fervidus sp. nov.
Cells are sluggishly motile, rod-shaped organisms 0.65 to 0.75 μm wide by 2 to 2.5 μm long and have rounded to slightly tapered ends.
They occur singly and rarely in pairs or in chains.
They stain gram negative, with many cells having a gram-positive granular protoplasm.
Under the phase-contrast microscope, these granules appear as small spherical refractile bodies.
Surface colonies are 2 to 3 mm in diameter, smooth, entire, and opaque after 24 h of incubation anaerobically.
The spores are spherical, subterminal to terminal, and do not swell the sporangium (Fig. 1A).
Thin sections of cells reveal the presence of a gram-positive, single-layered cell wall (Fig. 1B).
Ferments yeast extract and Trypticase peptone, and requires yeast extract or Trypticase peptone to ferment pyruvate, glucose, maltose, xylan, and starch.
The fermentation products from glucose fermentation in the presence of Trypticase peptone are H2, CO2, acetate, i-butyrate, i-valerate, n-valerate, ethanol, and lactate.
Optimum temperature and pH for growth are 68°C (range, >37 and <80°C) and 7 to 7.5 (range, >5.5 and <9.0), respectively (Fig. 2).
Isolated from a geothermal spring (70°C, pH 7.2) in New Zealand.
The type strain is strain Rt4-B1T (ATCC 43204).
